http://www.castlefieldgallery.co.uk/

The daddy of all the Manchester museums is that of the Museum of Science and Industry. It is big, it is comprehensive and (happily for all of us) there’s lots of hands-on stuff to engage children (and adults): http://www.mosi.org.uk/

I am always enthralled by the air and space collection and the marvellous steam engines of many kinds, but there is so much that it will take a detailed exploration of their web site to discover just how much there is to see.

The John Rylands Library of Manchester University contains a valuable collection of rare books and manuscripts. Events and exhibitions vary enormously in content because of the extraordinary range of the collection: http://www.library.manchester.ac.uk/rylands/

There is a little spot of tranquillity in the neighbouring city of Salford, Ordsall Hall, a Tudor gem in an otherwise unprepossessing wilderness of urban sprawl.

http://www.salfordcommunityleisure.co.uk/culture/ordsall-hall

In the summer of 2002 Manchester hosted the Commonwealth Games: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2002_Commonwealth_Games

The sporting legacy has been considerable and lasting. Physically it has left Manchester with a world-class velodrome at the heart of the National Cycling Centre: http://www.nationalcyclingcentre.com/

and a fine stadium, now known as the Etihad Stadium, home to Manchester City Football Club: http://www.mcfc.co.uk/

On the other side of the city is Old Trafford, not one, but two sporting arenas. Old Trafford cricket ground is the home of Lancashire County Cricket Club and a frequent host of international test matches: http://www.lccc.co.uk/

Old Trafford football ground is known the world over as the home of Manchester United Football Club: http://www.manutd.com/Splash-Page.aspx

The spread of languages on its splash page is enough to recognise the club’s global influence. Tours of the ground are particularly popular.

According to Google, it is 33.9 miles from Manchester to Liverpool. By car, it will take you anything from 40 minutes to an hour or longer, according to the weight of traffic encountered, road works, accidents and so forth. According to Wikipedia, the Liverpool and Manchester Railway was the world’s first twin-track inter-urban railway in which all the trains were timetabled and ticketed. Part of the original station at the Manchester end survives as part of the Manchester Museum of Science and Industry: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool_and_Manchester_Railway

That part of the M62 motorway linking Manchester and Liverpool passes (north of Warrington) the site of RAF Burtonwood. This was, during the Second World War, the gateway to Europe for vast numbers of American troops. Sadly, there are few vestiges and the site is now a vast complex of commercial and industrial buildings. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RAF_Burtonwood

A comparison of the merits and demerits of Liverpool and Manchester may be invidious, but it will be fun for me – until the residents from either read this and bar me from entry to both!

As far as Liverpool is concerned it is a more imposing a city than Manchester. You may not like all its buildings, but its setting on a hill climbing from the waterfront is uplifting. There, at the top, are its two vast Cathedrals, the modern Roman Catholic one, the Metropolitan Cathedral of Christ the King: http://www.liverpoolmetrocathedral.org.uk/

and the Anglican one: http://www.liverpoolcathedral.org.uk/

The Anglican Cathedral is vast (though not as long as originally intended) and took 100 years to build. To hear a vast symphony orchestra in this acoustic is stunning, and the organ is one of the biggest and most powerful I have ever experienced – yes, I have played it! The Catholic Cathedral stands at the other end of the aptly named Hope Street. It had been intended that it should be a vast basilica and would have been the second largest church in the world. The design by Lutyens survives and there is a model of how the church would have been: https://localwiki.org/liverpool/Edwin_Lutyens’_Original_Liverpool_Catholic_Cathedral

The extensive crypt was in fact built. But after the Second World War there was no appetite for such opulence and eventually a competition was held for a completely different sort of cathedral, which was won by Sir Frederick Gibberd. Work began in 1962 and it was completed in 1967. It is striking in its appearance internally when the sun is shining. Both cathedrals are notably welcoming to visitors.

Roughly midway along Hope Street, connecting the two cathedrals, is the Philharmonic Hall, home to the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra. http://www.liverpoolphil.com/

The hall is 1930s art deco and was one of the better halls acoustically in the country until the advent of the recent exceptional halls such as Symphony Hall in Birmingham and Bridgewater Hall in Manchester. I have a very soft spot for the hall and for the Phil, with whom I worked as a producer much during the 1980s and 1990s.

On the opposite side of Hope Street are the Philharmonic Dining Halls, a period piece of a pub once described as ‘the most ornate pub in England.’ http://www.nicholsonspubs.co.uk/thephilharmonicdiningroomsliverpool/

Liverpool is, of course, well supplied with dramatic entertainment:

http://www.everymanplayhouse.com/

http://www.liverpooltheatres.com/empire.htm

http://www.liverpooltheatres.com/royalcourt.htm

There is also a Cavern Club, but it’s not the original: http://www.liverpooltheatres.com/cavern.htm#

The original, where the Beatles starred in their early years, was closed down in 1973: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Cavern_Club

The Beatles story is told in a museum in the revitalised Albert Dock area: http://www.beatlesstory.com/

And much is remembered or reconstructed on:

http://www.cavernclub.org/whats-on/event/magical-mystery-tour/

The waterfront is dominated by the Royal Liver Building http://www.royalliverbuilding.com/default.aspx

In front of it the Albert Dock blends historic architecture with modern amenities in an exciting way: http://www.albertdock.com/

On the must see list of most visitors is the Merseyside Maritime Museum, which tells many fascinating tales, not least those connected with the ill-fated RMS Titanic. Entry is free. http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/maritime/

Nothing now remains of the ‘Dockers’ Umbrella’ as the Liverpool Overhead Railway was known. I remember it, even though it was closed in the mid 1950s. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool_Overhead_Railway

It ran along the waterfront past the splendid liners that used to ply between Liverpool and Canada, Australia, the far east, South Africa. They, too, are now a thing of the past, although some huge cruise liners call at Liverpool, dwarfing all around them.

Before the docks were constructed the River Mersey washed the walls of the Church of Our Lady and St Nicholas, Liverpool Parish Church, or St Nick’s as it is known locally. It is a reminder that when the estuary of the River Dee silted up, Chester was no longer able to enjoy a thriving port. Shipping moved to the little fishing village of Liverpool. How it has grown through the centuries! http://www.livpc.co.uk/

We should not take our leave of the Albert Dock area without visiting the Tate Liverpool art gallery: http://www.tate.org.uk/visit/tate-liverpool

There is another outstanding art gallery in Liverpool, the Walker Art Gallery. http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/walker/

Its collection ranges from the renaissance right through to David Hockney, Lucian Freud and Bridget Riley. Walkers brewed beer, but when the gallery was first opened it was on a Sunday. Sundays in those times were ‘dry’. A visitor misquoted Coleridge: ‘Walker, Walker, everywhere, Nor any drop to drink!’

The Walker is in an imposing part of the city with the St George’s Hall dominating everything. It is a huge building, in its day accommodating 4,000 people for its free Sunday organ recitals. Nowadays it is more likely to host conferences, weddings and other functions. Its interior may not be to everyone’s taste, but it is undeniably impressive. http://liverpoolcityhalls.co.uk/st-georges-hall

A visit to the newly restored Liverpool Central Library should be built into this part of town, with its well presented collections of historic books and handsome reading rooms. http://liverpool.gov.uk/libraries/find-a-library/central-library/

The most historic building in central Liverpool is the Bluecoat, dating from the 18th century. It has always been associated with the arts, particularly under the guidance of Augustus John. Great composers, jazz musicians, dancers and writers have performed or appeared here. http://www.thebluecoat.org.uk/

Of greater antiquity, however, is Speke Hall, a part Tudor building overlooking he Mersey estuary. Unfortunately it also overlooks the unsightly mess that is John Lennon Liverpool Airport. http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/speke-hall/

http://www.liverpoolairport.com/

Liverpool is particularly well provided with green spaces, its big parks, Sefton and Stanley, notable for their size: http://liverpool.gov.uk/leisure-parks-and-events/parks-and-greenspaces/

Bigger still, is the impressive Knowsley Safari Park: http://www.knowsleysafariexperience.co.uk/#&panel1-2

Notice that it is only open at weekends in the winter.

One of the world’s best-known race meetings takes place in the Liverpool suburb of Aintree, the Grand National: http://aintree.thejockeyclub.co.uk/

(There are, of course, other race meetings throughout the season).

Liverpool is synonymous with football. Two clubs have dominated proceedings in the city for many, many years:

Everton: http://www.evertonfc.com/home

And Liverpool: http://www.liverpoolfc.com/welcome-to-liverpool-fc

I’m not a big fan of shopping, and rows and rows of department stores cheek by jowl fill me with horror. But I have to say that I rather like Liverpool One. It has got space and even a touch of good taste: http://www.liverpool-one.com/

And, if your spirits need lifting, call in at Lunya, a Spanish deli, bar, café and restaurant right in the middle. It has just been awarded ‘North West restaurant of the year’ in the Good Food Guide. A few tapas and the odd cerveza make a wonderful pick-me-up: http://lunya.co.uk/

While golfers will never tire of that wonderful range of sand dunes stretching from Crosby to Southport I am afraid non-golfers have it pretty thin in this part of the county. Nature lovers might profitably walk in the pine woods at Formby hoping to spot some of the few remaining red squirrels in this country: http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/formby/

And autumn is a great time to go bird watching at Martin Mere:

http://www.wwt.org.uk/wetland-centres/martin-mere/

Near Ormskirk is Rufford Old Hall, a late mediaeval timber-framed building with plaster panels:

http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/rufford-old-hall/

Parts of Halsall Parish Church date back to the 14th century and contain fine carvings in wood and stone: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_Cuthbert’s_Church,_Halsall

Ormskirk Parish Church is older still, with its chancel dating back to 1270 and a Norman window to a hundred years before that: http://www.ormskirkparishchurch.org.uk/

However, if the weather is bad you may have to resort to the British Lawnmower Museum in Southport! http://www.lawnmowerworld.co.uk/

So, to the rest of Lancashire.

We have not done with the big industrial towns and cities with Bolton, Wigan, Blackburn, Burnley and Preston trying to drag themselves (and their football teams) out of the 19th century and into the 21st. Although our daughter teaches in Wigan I am more aware of goings on in Blackburn because I have been lucky enough to take part in many concerts in the Cathedral: http://www.blackburncathedral.com/

It is really rather a remarkable place, with a lot of music going on, much of it quite ambitious, such as period performances of the major Bach sacred works. I have also been honoured to join their choir as a soloist on a concert tour to Malta. As a place of worship the cathedral builds important bridges with the other faiths prevalent in Blackburn. In fact it can be quite surreal singing there. You drive in through seas of Islamic costumes. Then you enter the cathedral, rehearse your Monteverdi Vespers (or whatever) in a wholly different atmosphere and environment and follow that with the public performance. And then you leave the cathedral at, say, ten o’clock at night and find yourself driving through hordes of young white people, most of them drunk, and most of them wearing next to nothing, even though it is the middle of winter! But it is the Monteverdi you retain in the memory as you hit the motorway towards home.

Blackburn Rovers have had periods in the top flight of British football, but not recently: http://www.rovers.co.uk/

Bolton has quite impressive civic buildings and a handsome parish church:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolton_Town_Hall

http://boltonparishchurch.co.uk/

Its football club was one of the big names in England and its stadium is attractive, but it is no longer the force it once was:

http://www.bwfc.co.uk/

Of particular merit is Smithills Hall, a couple of miles from the town centre. http://www.boltonmuseums.org.uk/historic-halls/smithills-history

Turton Tower is a few miles further north and well worth a visit, with a very long history: http://www.turtontower.co.uk/

Driving along the M6 you will see signs to Wigan Pier. Many northern seaside towns have piers stretching for miles into the sea. It is not the same at Wigan, for it is not on the sea! For the story, here is a link: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wigan_Pier

Wigan’s football team, Wigan Athletic, is known as the ‘Latics’ and the club has led a charmed life over the last few seasons, managing to survive somehow in the Premier League despite its low budget. http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/

The town’s rugby league side has a long history of success: http://www.wiganwarriors.com/

Their arch rivals over many years have been St Helen’s: http://www.saintsrlfc.com/

I cannot think of any other reason to visit St Helen’s unless you have relations living there!

In 2002 Preston was made a city, the 50th English city in the 50th year of the Queen’s reign. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_of_Preston,_Lancashire

My advice would be not to bother making the detour to look at it. Carry on up the M6 towards greater beauties, or head off down the M55 if you want to prove your golfing prowess over Royal Lytham’s testing course. Unfortunately your non-golfing friends will find little to attract them to this, the Fylde, unless they are young at heart when they might enjoy the excitement of the hair-raising rides at Blackpool Pleasure Beach: http://www.blackpoolpleasurebeach.com/

For 120 years Blackpool Tower has looked out from a dizzying height over the miles of sand exposed when the tide goes out (some two miles out!) and its ballroom has a fame of its own: http://www.theblackpooltower.com/

Blackpool can boast not one, not two, but three piers, with rides, theatre shows and all sorts of ancillary events to keep visitors in the town when the boarding houses are shut for the day:

http://www.centralpierblackpool.co.uk/

http://www.southpierblackpool.co.uk/

http://www.northpierblackpool.co.uk/

Don’t forget to take a ride on the tram:

http://www.thetrams.co.uk/blackpool/

And if you are around in the autumn, the holiday season is prolonged by switching on the Blackpool Illuminations:

http://www.visitblackpool.com/illuminations/

Personally, from Preston I would prefer to turn not towards the sea but inland by some 10 miles to Ribchester. You can tell from its name that it is an old place, Roman, indeed. But it is in fact even older, with links to the bronze age. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ribchester

There is a charming little Roman museum:

http://ribchesterromanmuseum.org/

St Wilfrid’s Church, Stydd Alms houses, the White Bull pub and Ribchester Bridge are all worth a look, and, if you can be there when Ribchester’s arts festival is on, all the better, for the performers are often stars of the future:

http://www.saintwilfrids.org.uk/

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stydd

http://www.thewhitebullribchester.co.uk/

http://www.ribchesterfestival.co.uk/

Ribchester is one of the places listed as having one of the traceable Roman roads to be found in Lancashire: http://www.lancashire.gov.uk/environment/historichighways/roman.asp

Nearby is Samlesbury Hall, of great antiquity, and almost seeming more black than white to my eye. It has a reputation as one of the most haunted houses in England.

http://www.samlesburyhall.co.uk/

Most of us go as fast as we can up the M6 or M61 to get to the main attractions of Lancashire and beyond. It is very easy to avoid Chorley on either road. It would be a shame to miss out on Astley Hall: http://chorley.gov.uk/Pages/AtoZ/Astley-Hall.aspx

And there is a wonderful cheese shop (Pat’s) in Chorley Market, with the most exquisite Lancashire cheese, light, curdy and very moreish: http://www.patsmarketcheeseshop.co.uk/

Chorley is also home to the Chorley Cake, of which there are many derivatives in the locality, such as Sad Cake: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chorley_cake

The more famous Eccles Cake comes from Eccles, which is a suburb of Manchester: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eccles_cake

They are mass-produced and readily available in supermarkets up and down the land – and none the worse for being mass-produced; they are very good, even if their nicknames such as squashed fly cake do not immediately attract!

East of Preston the countryside becomes more attractive, with hills and dales forming the foothills on the Pennines. The drive through to Clitheroe is pleasing, as is the town when you get there. Clitheroe has a delightful parkland golf course with a welcoming club. Non golfers have plenty to occupy them, beginning at the castle:

http://new.lancashire.gov.uk/leisure-and-culture/museums/clitheroe-castle-museum.aspx

There are a number of traditional shops including the appropriately named Cowman’s – a specialist in sausages:

http://www.cowmans.co.uk/

And in this part of Lancashire there is only one place to consider buying your wine, Byrne’s: http://www.dbyrne-finewines.co.uk/

Not only are their wines amazing in their number and variety, but also the shopping experience is something special. No glamour, no glitz, just a hole in the wall where you step from the shop front into the cellar, wall to wall with wooden cases of the finest burgundies and clarets, all sorts of rarities from little-known wine regions and some remarkably inexpensive bargains, too.

Unusually, the parish church which had served the town for around 900 years was dismantled during the 19th century and rebuilt. http://www.stmaryclitheroe.com/

The Royal Grammar School was founded in 1554, although a school is thought to have existed since the 13th century. http://www.crgs.org.uk/

Nearby is the pretty village of Whalley, with its fine, old (13th century) parish church https://sites.google.com/site/whalleyparishchurch/

and the remains of Whalley Abbey, used as a retreat and conference centre for Blackburn diocese along with being an upmarket wedding venue. http://www.whalleyabbey.org/

Of salutary interest is the extraordinary tale of the Pendle Witches, now something of cause celebre, but frightening in its day: http://www.pendlewitches.co.uk/

Also in this neck of the woods is Stonyhurst College, one of the senior Roman Catholic schools in England, with its important library, small but significant arts centre, and flourishing sports centre. http://www.stonyhurst.ac.uk/

I have to say that, unless you are in a hurry to get to some specific spot, it’s a good idea to leave the map behind and just follow your nose. You may stray over into the Yorkshire dales, you may find your way back to the lowlands of west Lancashire, but you can drive all the way up to the Scottish border through very beautiful countryside, on roads rarely busy, through little villages and the occasional small town while sensing that little has changed in centuries. While Yorkshire has its famed Dales, Lancashire enjoys the delights of Bowland and its so-called Forest (forest, here, meaning an ancient hunting ground, not a mass of trees, which this most certainly is not). http://www.forestofbowland.com/

If you want to explore this part of the country, you might consider basing yourself at http://www.innatwhitewell.com/

Those of us who don’t wish to potter about on the little roads of Bowland are probably speeding north up the M6 and, once past Preston, the traffic density decreases noticeably. Fifty or sixty years ago, before the M6 was completed, traffic regularly ground to a halt in Lancaster. Nowadays we tend to race past it, which is a pity, because it has its merits. Its early history predates the Romans. We are aware of Norman activity in Lancaster, and Royal connections are centuries old. It is not a history for the sensitive, with bloodshed, executions, purging of witches and much more besides, but the history of England was bloody: http://www.lancastercastle.com/

http://www.visitlancashire.com/explore/lancaster

Lancaster stands on either side of the River Lune, its estuary emptying into Morecambe Bay, one of the great wildlife habitats remaining in Britain. Bird watchers flock to Hest Bank: http://www.rspb.org.uk/discoverandenjoynature/seenature/reserves/guide/m/morecambebay/

From here it is possible to walk across the bay to Grange-over-Sands (7 or 8 miles) but you need to know what you are doing: http://www.aboutbritain.com/towns/hest-bank.asp

http://www.virtual-lancaster.net/whatson/baywalk.htm

Morecambe Bay shrimps are some of the best in the world, but professional shrimpers have died in the treacherous sands and tides of Morecambe Bay. Beware!

Morecambe itself is rather a faded seaside resort, although American visitors may be interested to know that ancestors of George Washington once owned the site of the open-air market. There is a rather stronger Washington family link with Wharton, a part of Carnforth , close to Lancaster: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warton,_Lancaster

Neighbouring Heysham makes few demands on the visitor other than the ruins of St Patrick’s Chapel, which was probably started by the Angles, as long ago as the 8th or 9th century: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_Patrick’s_Chapel,_Heysham

We near the end of Lancashire, despite its size, but before indulging in the manifold treasures of the Lake District we ought to mention a few other Lancashire gems we have, so far, ignored.

Rochdale is a case in point, a rather moth-eaten town on the western slopes of the Pennines just off the M62 heading for Yorkshire. It’s an ancient town dating back to pre-Roman times and its early wealth came from wool. By the end of the 18th century cotton spinning (a vast Lancastrian industry in the 19th century) was replacing wool, with huge mills created to house an enormous number of workers slaving away from earliest dawn. Poverty was common and it was against this background that a group of visionaries set up the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers in 1844, recognised today as the very first Co-operative Society. http://www.rochdalepioneersmuseum.coop/

Near Carnforth, Borwick Hall is run as an outdoor pursuits centre http://www.lancashire.gov.uk/corporate/web/?siteid=5262&pageid=27861&e=e

While Leighton Hall is renowned as the seat of the Gillow family. http://www.leightonhall.co.uk/

The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds runs an important reserve at Leighton Moss: http://www.rspb.org.uk/discoverandenjoynature/seenature/reserves/guide/l/leightonmoss/

My old Shell Guide to England is so old that Cumbria hadn’t been invented, so I’m charmed to be able to include Cartmel in Lancashire. It lies inland of Grange-over-Sands by only a few miles and there’s a very characterful little 9-hole golf course at Grange Fell which offers spectacular views of the fells of the southern lakes and the Irish Sea. Cartmel Priory was founded in 1188 and much of it survives. It is a very beautiful church in an uplifting setting. http://www.cartmelpriory.org.uk/Home

The village as a whole is charming and immaculately kept. Of particular note is the village shop, nationally famous for its Sticky Toffee Pudding – disastrous for the waist line, but irresistible if you like your puddings seriously sweet! http://www.cartmelvillageshop.co.uk/

There are pubs and restaurants aplenty but if you have a fat wallet (and can manage to get a booking) then L’Enclume is the place to eat and drink: http://www.lenclume.co.uk/sr/ In 2014 the Good Food Guide rated it top of all the restaurants in Britain, its chef, Simon Rogan, drawing inspiration from local ingredients and their relationship with the world about. It is a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

I shall also allow myself to include Barrow-in-Furness in Lancashire in order to visit Furness Abbey, once one of the most powerful monastic houses in England: http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/properties/furness-abbey/

The ruins of one of Furness Abbey’s daughter monasteries have part survived at Calder Abbey. It is not generally open to the public, but there are occasional open days: http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/calderbridge-calder-abbey-ruins/

And while you are in this part make sure to acquaint yourself with the handsome town buildings of Broughton-in-Furness: http://www.visitcumbria.com/sl/broughton-in-furness/

The gardens of Holker Hall, owned by the Cavendish family, are among the finest in the north of England, and its herd of fallow deer is one of the oldest and largest in the country: http://www.holker.co.uk/

Ulverston was the birthplace of Stan Laurel, but there is much more to this pleasant old town, not least long Quaker connections, The Hoad lighthouse, and the stone circle on Birkrigg Common: http://www.visitulverston.com/

http://www.visitcumbria.com/sl/birkrigg-druids-circle/

Art lovers familiar with JMW Turner’s work will know his Crook O’ Lune, one of a series of representations of Richmondshire (in Yorkshire) http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/turner-crook-of-lune-looking-towards-hornby-castle-t04471/text-catalogue-entry

Visitors to Caton (in Lancashire) can see for themselves this very spot, perhaps enjoying a walk in delightful countryside, or a good, old-fashioned picnic! http://www.citycoastcountryside.co.uk/things-to-do/crook-o-lune-and-picnic-sites-p11664

For my convenience I am going to deal with Cumbria in alphabetic order, which means that I start with the highest market town in England, Alston. It’s almost 1,000 feet above sea level and features a handsome market cross, a number of historic houses and ample accommodation for walkers (many tramping the Pennine Way) and riders, narrow gauge rail enthusiasts, and even a few golfers who enjoy the open spaces of Alston Moor Golf Club, at 1,476 feet the highest course in England. http://www.alstonmoorgolfclub.org.uk/

http://www.visitcumbria.com/evnp/alston/

The drive over the Pennines from Penrith to Hexham is one of the finest in the country, climbing to 1,904 feet at Hartside. http://www.visitcumbria.com/evnp/hartside-pass/

Ambleside is a bustling little town on the shores of Windermere. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/ambleside/

It is mostly a 19th-century development, fostered by the opening of the ferry terminal in 1845. It is still possible to take ferries to Bowness and Lakeside. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/windermere-lake-cruises/

As in much of the Lake District, car parking can be problematic. The Armitt Museum (opposite the main car park) is a useful source of information on Wordsworth, Ruskin and Beatrix Potter http://www.visitcumbria.com/the-armitt-museum/

Bridge House is, these days, an information centre for the National Trust but it was formerly an apple store built over the river to avoid land tax!

http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/bridge-house/

Parts of the old Roman fort of Galava survive:

http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/galava-roman-fort/

Appleby was the county town of Westmorland until the formation of Cumbria. It is an attractive town with a wide main street dominated by its castle. http://www.applebytown.org.uk/

The castle is privately owned but there are tours for small parties: http://www.applebytown.org.uk/index.php?page=appleby-castle

Appleby Horse Fair takes place in early June and attracts visitors and participants from considerable distances: http://www.applebytown.org.uk/index.php?page=horse

For my taste, the organ in St Lawrence’s Church is one of the most interesting in the country. It was built for Carlisle Cathedral in 1661 by Robert Preston and given to St Lawrence’s in 1683, complete with its original case and is one of the three oldest playable organs in the country: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_Lawrence’s_Church,_Appleby

Bassenthwaite is both a village and a lake. Place names ending in ‘thwaite’ are common in the Lake District and the Yorkshire Dales, indicating that they were settled by Norsemen, thwaite being a cleared place. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bassenthwaite

Bassenthwaite Lake (the only lake in the Lake District!) is one of the larger lakes, about 4 miles long, but also one of the shallowest, only 70 feet deep at most. Osprey were re-introduced to the lake in 2001.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bassenthwaite_Lake

Boot is an old mining town, for which a narrow gauge railway was built to transport ore to the coast at Ravenglass, seven miles away. Passengers were soon carried and the railway continues to carry passengers in large numbers, being one of the Lake District’s major tourist attractions: http://ravenglass-railway.co.uk/ (See also Eskdale)

It was at Seathwaite in Borrowdale that graphite was mined to make Keswick pencils. In days past iron was smelted, charcoal burned and copper mined. Today Borrowdale survives on tourism. Brandlehow Woods was the first property bought by the National Trust, back in 1902, and in 1910 Princess Louise bought Grange Fell as a gift to the National Trust in memory of her brother, King Edward VII. In all, the National Trust owns 29,000 acres in Borrowdale including half of Derwentwater. http://www.visitcumbria.com/kes/borrowdale/

Bowness-on-Windermere is really an extension of the town of Windermere, enjoying the many facilities of England’s largest lake. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/bowness-on-windermere/

The parish church of St Martin is the most interesting building in Bowness. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/bowness-on-windermere-st-martins-church/

Braithwaite, a little to the west of Keswick, is a convenient centre for climbing the Grasmoor mountains and provides a scenic drive to Bassenthwaite Lake. http://www.visitcumbria.com/kes/braithwaite/

High above Braithwaite in the Coledale Valley can be found Force Crag Mine, the last working metal mine in the Lake District, now a Site of Special Scientific Interest and a scheduled ancient monument. http://www.visitcumbria.com/cm/force-crag-mine/

Brothers’ Water is a quiet spot sheltering below the crags of Helvellyn. It is said that the name of the lake was changed (from Broadwater) after two brothers drowned there. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/brothers-water/

Nearby, Hartsop Hall is now maintained by the National Trust:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hartsop

Brough, in the east of Cumbria, in what was true Westmorland, is an ancient parish divided by the busy A66 road from Penrith east across the Pennines. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brough,_Cumbria

The remains of Brough Castle stand within the old Roman fort of Veteris. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brough_Castle

St Michael’s Church is historic and handsome: http://www.visitcumbria.com/evnp/brough-st-michaels-church/

Brough Castle was one of the homes of the powerful Clifford family, as was Brougham Castle just outside Penrith. http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/properties/brougham-castle/

If you can, make time to visit also St Ninian’s Church, known as Ninekirks: http://www.visitchurches.org.uk/Ourchurches/Completelistofchurches/St-Ninians-Church-Brougham-Cumbria/

as well as St Wilfrid’s Chapel with its wonderful mediaeval woodwork: http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/brougham-st-wilfreds-church/

Buttermere is the name of both a lake and a village. Here good rambling, walking and fishing abound. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buttermere

The Maid of Buttermere is a character in Book VII of The Prelude by Wordsworth. She was the daughter of the landlord of the Fish Inn and had the misfortune to marry a forger and bigamist who was later hanged. After her death she was buried in the churchyard of St Kentigern’s, Caldbeck. Few visitors will notice her tomb, but many will spot that of John Peel, the master huntsman: http://www.visitcumbria.com/car/caldbeck-st-kentigerns-church/

It has been said of Carlisle that it has probably suffered the longest period of unrest of any English town or city. From the arrival of the Romans in 80 AD until the suppression of the Jacobite Rising in 1745 warfare, struggle, strife and family feuding dominated everyday life in Carlisle. Even after that the city has seen huge social problems of overcrowded and unsanitary housing, drunkenness and prostitution, and as recently as 1994 The Independent on Sunday reported that the Raffles district was a no-go area. The sorry tale is told: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlisle,_Cumbria

But my personal experience of Carlisle has been entirely happy. On many occasions I have taken part in concerts at the Cathedral. It is a diminutive building, much wrecked in troublesome times past, and yet it somehow remains attractive and wonderfully quiet compared with the world of Mammon only just outside the church. http://www.carlislecathedral.org.uk/

I have a particular fondness for the Cathedral organ, resolutely Victorian and none the worse for it: http://www.carlislecathedral.org.uk/the_cathedral_organ

Carlisle Castle has seen many fractious encounters and has, in consequence, been rebuilt or modified much through the centuries. But it still stands and is well worth a visit: http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/properties/carlisle-castle/

Carlisle Citadel is a pair of towers originally erected at the order of King Henry VIII. They are open to visitors in the summer months: http://www.discovercarlisle.co.uk/lifestyle/attractions/citadel.aspx

The historic part of central Carlisle has miraculously survived all the strife of centuries and is home to a worthwhile museum, Tullie House: http://www.discovercarlisle.co.uk/lifestyle/attractions/tullie-house.aspx

‘Discover Carlisle’ lists a number of other attractions and entertainments for the visitor: http://www.discovercarlisle.co.uk/lifestyle/attractions/

Six miles north-west of Carlisle, Burgh-by-Sands church is heavily fortified and constructed of Roman stones: http://www.visitcumbria.com/car/burgh-by-sands-st-michaels-church/

There is another at Newton Arlosh: http://www.visitcumbria.com/car/newton-arlosh-st-johns-church/

And yet another at Great Salkeld: http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/great-salkeld-st-cuthberts-church/

Carrock Fell is situated some 8 miles north-east of Keswick, in the very north of the National Park. It is esteemed by fell walkers and geologists alike and during both World Wars and the Korean War it was the site for vigorous mining activity, being the only source of Tungsten north of Devon and Cornwall. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrock_Fell

Sir Walter Scott’s poem The Bridal of Triermain refers to Castle Rock in St John’s Vale, near Thirlmere. It is a most handsome spot, although climbs on the rock are said to be severe. http://www.geog.port.ac.uk/webmap/thelakes/html/lgaz/lk02236.htm

Great Dodd and High Rigg are among the favourite hills of ramblers in this part of the lakes, and it is on the upper slopes of High Rigg that the church of St John’s in the Vale is to be found. It is still a functioning church despite its remote location. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_John’s_Church,_St_John’s_in_the_Vale

Speeding along the M6 motorway or West Coast main railway line you are unlikely to be aware of the little village of Clifton a few miles to the south of Penrith. Yet it is a historic spot, for here was fought the last battle on English soil, in 1745 between Bonnie Prince Charlie’s forces, in retreat after their defeat at Derby, and those of the Duke of Cumberland. After the battle some of the dead were buried in St Cuthbert’s Church. Clifton may also have been the site of a battle against Roman forces in 69 AD (although this is disputed) and is also referred to in Sir Walter Scoot’s Waverley. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clifton,_Cumbria

The rivers Cocker and Derwent meet at Cockermouth and this confluence was of strategic importance to the Romans who built a fort at Papcastle. Stones from this fort were later (12th century) used to construct a castle which was subsequently ravaged by Robert the Bruce’s soldiers and also in the Civil War. http://www.cockermouth.org.uk/

Today Cockermouth is famed for its speciality shops and Georgian Fair but it should not be forgotten that Cockermouth was also the birthplace of the eminent scientist, John Dalton; leader of the mutiny on the Bounty, Fletcher Christian; and the Wordsworths, William and Dorothy. The Society of Friends has long been associated with Cockermouth (since the 1650s). Its historic first meeting house could not accommodate the huge numbers attending meetings, which had to be held outdoors at Pardew Crag. A new meeting house was built in 1728 and that, along with its graveyard, survives: http://www.visitcumbria.com/cm/pardshaw-quaker-meeting-house/

Coniston is both a town and a lake (Coniston Water). It is a pretty lake, backed by mountains and wooded hills. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/coniston-water/

Chief of the surrounding hills is Coniston Old Man. http://www.walklakes.co.uk/walk_2.html

It was on Coniston Water that Donald Campbell was killed in 1967 attempting to break the world water speed record. The Ruskin Museum includes Campbell’s history and many memorabilia. http://www.ruskinmuseum.com/

The Lakeland Motor Museum at Ulverston also contains Campbell (father and son) artefacts. http://www.lakelandmotormuseum.co.uk/

John Ruskin bought Brantwood, a house overlooking Coniston Water, in 1871 and it remains a memorial to him as well as hosting cultural events, study courses and tours of its famous gardens. http://www.brantwood.org.uk/

Arthur Ransome based his book Swallows and Amazons in the area around Coniston Water.

It is worth strolling up to Tarn Hows for the fine views afforded over Coniston Water and the surrounding fells. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/tarn-hows/

In Eastern Cumbria, near Kirkby Stephen, is the parish church of St Andrew at Crosby Garrett. It dates from the 11th century and part of an interior arch is reckoned to date from Saxon times. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_Andrew%27s_Church,_Crosby_Garrett

In 2010 a roman helmet was discovered near Crosby Garrett, which sold at auction for £2.3 million.

Between Shap and Appleby is the village of Crosby Ravensworth, with its handsome parish church, often described as a cathedral in miniature, and 7th century cross shaft. http://www.visitcumbria.com/evnp/crosby-ravensworth/

A couple of miles away is Ewe Close, believed to date from the iron age, one of a number of ancient settlements in the area. http://www.visitcumbria.com/evnp/ewe-close/

Crosscanonby overlooks the Irish Sea near Maryport. A roman milefortlet has been resurrected along with Elizabethan saltpans. Former roman stones were used in the construction of the church of St John the Evangelist. http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/crosscanonby/

Crosscanonby Carr is a recently established nature reserve http://www.solwaycoastaonb.org.uk/crosscarr.php

Crummock Water lies close to Buttermere, and may once have been joined to it. http://www.visitcumbria.com/cm/crummock-water/

Nearby Scale Force is reckoned to be the highest waterfall in the Lake District. http://www.visitcumbria.com/cm/scale-force/

Dacre, a few miles west of Penrith, is a village with a historic church, castle and pele towers. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dacre,_Cumbria

The church houses two very old (one pre-Viking) cross shafts and an ancient floor. http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/dacre-st-andrews-church/

The pele towers were built to protect residents from attack by vast marauding armies of Scotsmen during the reign of King Edward I. http://www.visitcumbria.com/pele/

Dacre Castle is one such: http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/dacre-castle/

It stands within the grounds of Dalemain House: http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/dalemain/

Derwentwater is one of the most attractive of the lakes, surrounded by high mountains, and conveniently supplied with a road all the way round it. Of its islands, Lord’s Island was once the residence of the Earls of Derwentwater. http://www.visitcumbria.com/kes/derwentwater/

Wordsworth was inspired by the Duddon Valley, or more properly by the Reverend Robert Walker of Seathwaite, to compose 35 of his sonnets. The river traditionally divided Cumberland from Lancashire. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duddon_Valley

Egremont is hardly the prettiest small town in Cumbria, having a history of mining, dyeing and weaving. Its Florence Mine was the last working deep iron ore mine in Western Europe. The remains of Egremont Castle are Norman. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egremont,_Cumbria

The town boasts a very old fair, dating from 1267. The Egremont Crab Fair attracts visitors from far and wide, necessitating the closure of the main street: http://www.egremontcrabfair.com/

To fruit lovers and gardeners the name Egremont is always linked with the Egremont Russet apple, one of the finest varieties for the English climate. It is believed to have first been raised by the Earl of Egremont on his estate in Sussex in 1872. https://www.rhs.org.uk/Plants/49442/Malus-domestica-Egremont-Russet-(D)/Details

Elterwater, it seems, means the lake frequented by swans and, indeed, Whooper Swans can be seen there during the winter months. It is an area still bearing the scars of mining, which was its principal activity. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/elterwater/

Former President Bill Clinton proposed to his wife, Hillary, on the banks of Ennerdale Water in 1973. It is the most westerly of all the lakes, and only infrequently visited because you have to make an effort to find it. The area is maintained as a Site of Special Scientific Interest. http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/ennerdale-water/

Mention was made earlier of the Ravenglass Railway. It chuffs through the gentle countryside of lower Eskdale. Upper Eskdale, however, is a place of high mountains, not least Scafell Pike, England’s highest mountain. http://www.eskdale.info/

And if you intend to drive through Eskdale and over the mountains to Langdale you will encounter Hardknott Pass, which is narrow, tortuous, the joint steepest road in England and there are no safety fences! Don’t miss the remains of Hardknott Roman Fort. Can you imagine being garrisoned here in mid winter? http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardknott_Pass

Esthwaite Water is a pretty little lake situated between Windermere and Coniston. It is particularly renowned for its trout fishing and winter pike fishing: http://www.hawksheadtrout.com/

Grasmere is closely associated with the Lake poets, principally William Wordsworth who lived here in Dove Cottage. The village’s fame brings tourists in swarms and in summer it can be impossible to find somewhere to park. Wordsworth described Grasmere as ‘the loveliest spot that man hath ever found.’ Thomas Gray called it ‘this little unsuspected paradise.’ http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/grasmere/

First time visitors will wish to see Dove Cottage, now a museum dedicated to the memory of William, his sister, Dorothy, and wife, Mary. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/dove-cottage-wordsworth-museum/

Visitors will also wish to visit Wordsworth’s grave in the churchyard of St Oswald’s. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/grasmere-st-oswalds-church/

The church itself is dour from the outside, but inside it is delightful. There are other connections to the Wordsworths and the organ is very fine of its kind, beautifully voiced. Our younger son got married in St Oswald’s and I persuaded one of the finest organists in the country to play for the service. He was delighted with the instrument – and his fee was a round of golf at Silloth!

And if you happen to be in Grasmere in early August make sure to witness its Rushbearing ceremony: http://www.visitcumbria.com/rushbearing-festivals/

Grasmere Ginger Bread was popularised in the 19th century by Sarah Nelson. The shop still does a roaring trade. http://www.grasmeregingerbread.co.uk/

And, if you have a sweet tooth, don’t miss the Grasmere Chocolate Cottage: http://www.chocolatecottage.co.uk/

I have so far neglected the lake of Grasmere. It is most attractive, but the island in the middle, which Wordsworth liked to visit, is privately owned and not open to uninvited visitors. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/grasmere-lake/

Other poets who passed through Grasmere include Coleridge, Southey and de Quincey.

But there is another side to Cumbrian culture, the energetic side. Grasmere hosts one of the many popular sports meetings every August. It involves Cumberland Wrestling, Hound Trails and, of course, Fell Running. http://grasmeresports.com/

We watch with awe Olympic athletes pound around the steeplechase track, others tackle fearsome marathons, or overcome the tribulations of cross-country circuits. Fearless amateurs indulge in fell running in the Lake District as if it were an everyday farming activity. At Grasmere they have been fell running ‘for fun’ since 1850. If you want to prove how fit you are try Borrowdale’s 17-mile race which involves 6,500 feet of climbing including the ascent of Scafell Pike and Great Gable. http://www.thecumbriadirectory.com/Cumbria_Traditions/tradition_view.php?tradition=fell_racing

Great Gable is one of the most scenic of the Lake District’s peaks. It is not the highest mountain, coming in at just under 3,000 feet, but it is very satisfying to climb as you cannot really cheat! http://where2walk.co.uk/lake_district/classic_circuits/great-gable/?pid=1134

Returning to the neighbourhood of Penrith, Greystoke is about 5 miles to the west and features a fine, large parish church mostly dating from the 15th century. http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/greystoke/

The village itself is pretty and the castle was once the seat of descendants of the Duke of Norfolk, the premier duke in the Peerage of England, and a senior Roman Catholic.

When I first encountered Grisedale it had an s as its fourth letter. Now it seems to have been Americanized into Grizedale. No matter, it’s still a popular destination for walkers. There used to be a music festival at the Theatre in the Forest, but I think it must have folded. However, there is much art work scattered throughout. http://www.visitcumbria.com/sl/grizedale-forest/

http://www.golakes.co.uk/Hawkshead-Grizedale-Forest-Visitor-Centre/details/?dms=3&venue=5014559

Following alphabetical order Hadrian’s Wall should come next, but as it is shared equally by Cumberland and Northumberland I’ll hold it back for the end of this chapter.

Haweswater is a somewhat controversial reservoir in the east of the region. It was constructed in 1929 to supply Manchester with water. Villages, a church and graves were sacrificed and in periods of drought visitors return to view the ruins. http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/haweswater/

The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds maintains a bird reserve at Haweswater at which, occasionally, a Golden Eagle may make an appearance. http://www.rspb.org.uk/discoverandenjoynature/seenature/reserves/guide/h/haweswater/

Hawkshead these days is a traffic free zone. You park outside the village and walk. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/hawkshead/

There is much to see, not least the old grammar school of 1585: http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/hawkshead-old-grammar-school/

Only the Courthouse remains of the once extensive manor farm which existed here in monastic days, part of the Furness Abbey (qv) estates: http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/hawkshead-courthouse/

The Beatrix Potter Gallery is a must for all visitors to Hawkshead: http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/hawkshead-beatrix-potter-gallery/

Before the late 17th century Quakers were not allowed to congregate in towns. If they wanted to worship together they had to meet out of town, and the Friends’ Meeting House at Hawkshead is a little way distant at Colthouse: http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/colthouse-quaker-meeting-house/

Similarly Hawkshead’s historic Baptist Chapel is a mile or so outside the village. Happily, you can park there: http://www.hawksheadhillbaptistchurch.org.uk/welcome.htm

The Anglican Church of St Michael and All Angels looks out over the village: http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/hawkshead-st-michael-and-all-angels-church/

Slightly confusingly, the very popular Hawkshead Brewery is not in Hawkshead at all, but at Staveley, between Kendal and Windermere: https://www.hawksheadbrewery.co.uk/

Happily, for those intending to sample their beers in depth, the brewery is accessible by bus and by train.

Helvellyn, at 3,118 feet, is the third highest peak in the Lake District. http://www.helvellyn.com/

It is very popular with walkers, easily accessed, with fine views along its length.

If you are driving to Silloth to play golf your route may take you through Abbey Town. Holme Cultrum Abbey may not instantly catch your attention. It doesn’t look very old and appears to be a hotch-potch of architectural styles – which is what it is. But if you look inside there are fragments of the original mediaeval abbey well worthy of study: http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/holme-cultram-abbey/

The village on Ings, close to Windermere, possesses a pleasant 18th century church. But I suspect most visitors to the village come to drink beer. The Watermill Inn and Brewery boasts up to 16 real ales at any one time, all on hand pulls. http://www.watermillinn.co.uk/

The coming of the M6 motorway has greatly relieved congestion in Kendal. I am old enough to remember the town in the days before the M6. It was impossible to cross the main street in the height of summer. http://www.visitcumbria.com/sl/kendal/

Sadly, Kendal’s main industry, K shoes, didn’t make the cut and is no more. But there’s a nod in the right direction on the website of the outlet centre which now occupies the site: http://www.kvillage.co.uk/k-shoes-heritage-centre

Happily, one of Kendal’s more obscure industries still flourishes, the manufacture of snuff: http://www.samuelgawith.co.uk/

More famous, however, is Kendal Mint Cake: http://www.kendal.mintcake.co.uk/

It’s very sweet and it’s very good!

There’s not much in particular to attract the visitor to Kendal, the remains of a Norman castle and the attractive 18th century parish church excepted, but it’s one of those towns where the whole adds up to more than the sum of its parts. It is a lovely place.

Kendal is, as it were, the southern gateway to the Lakes. By the same reckoning Keswick might be said to be the northern gateway, and, like Kendal, it is also more than the sum of its parts. http://www.visitcumbria.com/kes/keswick/

Keswick enjoys a lovely setting near to Derwentwater and overlooked by the mountains Skiddaw and Saddleback. It was a home to many of the Lake poets. Coleridge lived here for a while, who was followed by Southey. Charles Lamb came on holiday and Shelley lived here for a time. Scott, Tennyson, Stevenson and Wordsworth patronized the Royal Oak Hotel. Manuscripts held by the Fitz Park Museum and Art Gallery include many by these as well as Hugh Walpole and John Ruskin. Ruskin also started a branch of his hand-made linen industry here and the School of Industrial Arts was founded by Canon HD Rawnsley in 1883. He was Vicar of Crossthwaite and a founder of the National Trust.

Crossthwaite Church has a remarkable history, traceable back to 553 AD. The present building was started in 1181, although there were many alterations throughout the centuries and what one sees today is mainly the hand of Sir George Gilbert Scott in 1844. http://www.visitcumbria.com/cm/crosthwaite-st-kentigerns-church/

Since 1832, when its first factory opened, Keswick pencils have been renowned for their quality. Although the factory was replaced by another, opening in the 1920s, fine pencils are still made in the town. All is revealed at the Cumberland Pencil Museum: http://www.pencilmuseum.co.uk/

Both Kirkbys, Kirkby Lonsdale and Kirkby Stephen, lie in the former county of Westmorland, somewhat divorced from the Lake District, more in keeping with the Pennines. Kirkby Lonsdale stands on the River Lune which is crossed here by one of England’s finest historic bridges, the Devil’s Bridge: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirkby_Lonsdale

Kirkby Lonsdale’s history is long, with a Neolithic stone circle at Casterton. (It was at Casterton that the four Bronte sisters were pupils). The Romans passed through Kirkby on their travels to and from Hadrian’s Wall. The centre of the town is handsome with old houses and shops, some of them continuing historic trades in local foods. St Mary’s Church is a Norman foundation, a good deal of which survives despite many ‘restorations’. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_Mary%27s_Church,_Kirkby_Lonsdale

Ruskin was particularly proud of the view of the River Lune, memorably captured by JMW Turner: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirkby_Lonsdale#mediaviewer/File:Ruskins_View.jpg

Kirkby Stephen has more moorland in its feel, being essentially a broad main street near to the source of the River Eden. http://www.kirkby-stephen.com/

St Stephen’s Church is a big one for what is essentially a village. It is impressive: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St_Stephen%27s_Church,_Kirkby_Stephen

The weekly market has been in existence since 1352/3 and brings vast numbers of cattle and sheep to the town every Monday. Around October Tup sales are held, reminding of the importance of sheep rearing in this part of the Pennines. Railway lovers rejoice that the old Settle-Carlisle line has been retained, despite many attempts to have it closed. Occasionally trains on it are still steam hauled. It runs about a mile from Kirkby Stephen: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Settle-Carlisle_Line

http://www.settle-carlisle.co.uk/

It is over the Settle-Carlisle line that vast trainloads of gypsum are transported to Kirkby Thore for processing. In fact Kirkby Thore was once the site of a Roman fort, Bravoniacum, and retains a part 12th century church.

http://www.visitcumbria.com/evnp/kirkby-thore/

http://www.visitcumbria.com/churches/kirkby-thore-st-michaels-church/

Kirkoswald is a village in the Eden Valley. Its church is unusual in that its bell tower is located some 200 yards away, on top of a hill. It has been suggested that it was so sited that villagers might hear its bells better. There is also a ruined castle (not open to the public) and the fine ‘College’, a handsome private house of the 16th and 17th centuries. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirkoswald,_Cumbria

At an altitude of 1,489 feet, Kirkstone Pass is the highest in the Lake District open to road vehicles. The inn close to its summit is the third highest in all England.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirkstone_Pass

I’m fond of Lanercost Priory, close to Hadrian’s Wall. It’s one of those places that, although largely ruined, continues to evoke much of the spirit and spirituality of the 12th century in which it was founded. However, some of the former priory survives intact, and very beautiful it is, too! Those surviving parts remain the local parish church: http://www.lanercostpriory.org.uk/

The ruins are cared for by English Heritage: http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/daysout/properties/lanercost-priory/

Langdale consists of two valleys (Great and Little Langdale) and their surrounding mountains. It is premium rambling and climbing country. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Langdale

The names of mountains hereabouts are poetry in themselves: Pike o’ Stickle, Harrison Stickle, Pavey Ark, Crinkle Crags and Pike o’ Blisco. Stickle Tarn (small lake) and Dungeon Ghyll Force (waterfall) attract walkers. A welcome pint awaits at the historic Old Dungeon Ghyll Hotel: http://www.odg.co.uk/home/index.cfm?id=1

It was here, as a young lad, that I came across for the first time that local speciality Cumberland Rum Butter, with home-made scones and whipped cream!

At Levens Bridge on the River Kent stands Levens Hall, a most attractive Elizabethan mansion. http://www.levenshall.co.uk/

Of particular interest inside the house are the plasterwork ceilings and oak chimney pieces, while outside pride of place is taken by the outstanding topiary gardens, retaining their original plan of 1689.

Loweswater is the most northerly lake in the Lake District, at the border between the fells proper and the coastal plain. It is a peaceful place, ideal for a gentle walk. http://www.visitcumbria.com/cm/loweswater-lake/

Lowther Castle, a few miles south of Penrith, was for centuries the home of the Earls of Lonsdale. It and its famous grounds fell into disrepair when they were used for military exercises during the Second World War. The family is now working in partnership with English Heritage to restore the gardens and make the buildings safe for visitors. http://www.lowthercastle.org/

The fact that the gardens were unmaintained for 70 years has meant that a rich variety of flora and fauna can be viewed by visitors: http://www.lowthercastle.org/wildlife-lowther

When the family left Lowther they lived at Askham Hall, which is now a country house hotel: http://www.askhamhall.co.uk/

If there is a sense of uniformity to the appearance of Maryport it is because the

Port was developed from a fishing village into a coal port by the Senhouse family in the 18th century. http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/maryport/

The maritime museum brings Maryport’s past to life: http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/maryport-maritime-museum/

In Roman times a fort, Alauna, guarded the village and important relics have been found. There are delightful sea views from the early holes at Maryport Golf Club: http://www.maryportgolfclub.co.uk/Home.aspx

Millom is a former iron and steel town on the far south-west tip of Cumbria. Following the closure of the works, Millom has seen hard times. http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/millom/

Millom Rugby League Club is one of the oldest amateur rugby league clubs in the world, founded in 1873. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millom_RLFC

Millom Museum is housed in the (still active) railway station and tells the story of the rise and fall of iron mining and steel making in the town. http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/millom-museum/

The former mine was at Hodbarrow where there is now a major RSPB bird sanctuary: http://www.rspb.org.uk/discoverandenjoynature/seenature/reserves/guide/h/hodbarrow/

The Church of the Holy Trinity in Millom is situated next to the ruins of a 14th/15th century castle. The church is older, with surviving Norman work as well as later stained glass and a fine sundial outside the church. http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/millom-holy-trinity-church/

Muncaster Castle has been the home of the Pennington family from the 13th century. Parts of the original castle were retained when the castle was reconstructed in the 19th century. http://www.muncaster.co.uk/

It is reputed to be haunted and you can even take part in an overnight ghost sit or ghost vigil! http://www.muncaster.co.uk/ghost-sits.html

The web site majors on events (weddings and corporate events) but the castle is still a family home, containing much fine furniture, and the 18th-century gardens are famous. http://www.muncaster.co.uk/gardens

Naworth Castle has a long history within the Dacre and Howard families: http://www.naworth.co.uk/history1_new.htm

It’s a reminder of how bloody life could be from the 14th century onwards, even for the wealthy and powerful. The castle isn’t normally open for visits but it can be arranged for small parties to stay overnight. The castle remains in the Howard family and can be made available for corporate events, conferences, weddings and so on. http://www.naworth.co.uk/index.htm

Newby Bridge is one of those villages in the South Lakes that has migrated from Lancashire to Cumbria. Its claim to fame is its stone bridge with arches of unequal size. http://www.visitcumbria.com/sl/newby-bridge/

The village is served by the Lakeside and Haverthwaite preserved railway. http://www.lakesiderailway.co.uk/

Newby Bridge Mansion was the first of its kind, overlooking the shores of Lake Windermere. It is now a conveniently situated hotel, but I have no personal experience of it. http://www.newbybridgehotel.co.uk/

St James’s Church at Ormside (west of the A66) is of considerable antiquity. http://www.visitcumbria.com/evnp/great-ormside-st-james-church/

Ormside Hall, nearby, incorporates a 14th/15th century pele tower into what is now a farmhouse. http://www.matthewpemmott.co.uk/2008/01/great-ormside.html

George Whitehead was a major influence in the development of the Society of Friends in the 17th century. He was born in Orton, a little village just north of Tebay: http://www.orton.org.uk/

The village has many pretty cottages from the 17th and 18th centuries. All Saints’ Church is mostly late mediaeval. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_Saints_Church,_Orton

Up near Hadrian’s Wall stands the little church of Upper (or Over) Denton. http://www.visitcumbria.com/churches/upper-denton-church/

Apparently stones from the wall were used in its construction (possibly in the time of the Anglo-Saxons, perhaps Norman).

Patterdale is a valley and village at the head of Ullswater. http://www.ullswater.co.uk/patterdale.html

It is a popular centre for climbing on the High Street group or the mountains of Helvellyn. St Patrick’s Church is mid-19th century, but there is a tradition that St Patrick, patron saint of Ireland, preached here in the 5th century. http://www.patterdaletoday.co.uk/church/church-history

The market town of Penrith is ancient and historic. http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/penrith/

It’s also a modern working town with the ubiquitous garden centres, DIY centres, supermarkets, road haulage depots and all the other paraphernalia of contemporary business. But the town centre still has a good number of traditional shops.

It is thought that the Celts were the earliest occupants of Penrith 500 B.C. The Romans built a road through Penrith to their fort of Voreda: http://www.roman-britain.org/places/voreda.htm

After their departure came the Norsemen and Angles and by the 9th and 10th centuries Penrith was the capital of Cumbria, a semi-independent state of the (Scottish) Kingdom of Strathclyde.

Testament to the violent history of Penrith are the ruins of Penrith Castle. http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/penrith-castle/ It’s dramatically situated on its old earthworks – and right in the middle of a busy traffic island!

There is great antiquity to the site of St Andrew’s, the parish church. http://www.standrewspenrith.org.uk/welcome.htm Today’s church buildings in part go back to Norman times, although the appeal of the interior is its Georgian classicism. Of particular curiosity out side is the Giant’s Grave: http://www.standrewspenrith.org.uk/giantsgrave.htm

Wordsworth connections with Penrith are several, including one of the 1791 houses today forming part of Penrith Town Hall, and formerly a residence of Wordsworth’s cousin, John. There is a pleasant walk around the Town Hall, Thacka Beck and Penrith Museum (located in a school building dating back to 1670) http://www.explorepenrith.org.uk/trail/stage1/

One very old pubs Penrith, The Gloucester Arms, is said to have been in existence since 1477, http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Restaurant_Review-g186328-d2400788-Reviews-Gloucester_arms-Penrith_Lake_District_Cumbria_England.html

And it seems the Two Lions was only a little more than a century younger (started in 1584), but it must have been closed since my (antiquated) guide book was published: http://www.geog.port.ac.uk/webmap/thelakes/html/lgaz/lk13587.htm

On a hill overlooking Penrith is Penrith Beacon, a comparatively modern structure (1719) in which beacons have been lit to warn of war or a dangerous emergency. http://www.visitcumbria.com/pen/penrith-beacon/

Pooley Bridge, on Ullswater, is a convenient boarding place for lake steamers. It is well placed for access from the M6, and (at the right time of the year) to view Wordsworth’s famous daffodils. http://www.ullswater.co.uk/pooley_bridge.html

Ravenstonedale is at the heart of a number of scattered villages south west of Kirby Stephen. It is pretty country and St Oswald’s Church (mostly 18th century) provides a handsome focus. http://www.ravenstonedale.org/

Rydal and Rydal Water are synonymous with Wordsworth. The poet moved to Rydal Mount in 1813, living there until his death in 1850. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/rydal-mount/

When, in 1847, his daughter Dora died, Wordsworth, his wife, sister and gardener planted a memorial garden to her next to St Mary’s Church. It is maintained by the National Trust. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/doras-field/

St Mary’s Church is quiet and simple, dating from 1824, but it has strong links with the Wordsworth and Arnold families, who worshipped there. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/rydal-st-marys-church/

From the higher ground in the vicinity (not least Rydal Mount) there are fine views over Rydal Water. http://www.visitcumbria.com/amb/rydal-water/

Nab Cottage, overlooking the Water was home to Thomas Quincey and Hartley Coleridge (son of Samuel Taylor Coleridge).

Saddleback, or Blencathra as it is often called, is one of the most distinctive mountains in the north of the Lake District. It is popular with fell walkers as a stiff climb, and the mile-long ridge on its summit gives magnificent views. But the mountain also achieved notoriety in May 2015 when it was sold by the Earl of Lonsdale. ‘Friends of Blencathra’ was quickly formed to try to buy off the sale, but failed: //www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/lake-district-mountain-sold-friends-of-blencathra-fail-to-buy-the-iconic-saddleback-9585832.html

St Bees Head is the most westerly point on the coast of Cumbria and host to a prolific seabird colony: http://www.rspb.org.uk/discoverandenjoynature/seenature/reserves/guide/s/stbeeshead/

The village of St Bees itself is little more than a small coastal resort but ut has a long history: http://www.visitcumbria.com/wc/st-bees/

St Bees School had a long history – 400 years – but it is scheduled to close at the end of the summer term 2015. It is a shame, but its location and other factors have brought about its demise: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-cumbria-31877302

St Bees Priory is older still, a remarkable foundation. Some of the building (notably a doorway) dates from Norman times, although most of the visible stonework is part of a ‘restoration’ of 1855 by William Butterfield. http://www.stbeespriory.org/#/about-us/building-history

Housed within the building is an extraordinary organ, one of the last masterpieces of the great Father Willis (1899). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Willis_%26_Sons

What is so stunning about the instrument at St Bees is that, housed in a small church, with little acoustic, you really can hear every single note in a way that you often can not in the vast acoustics of some of our grander cathedrals and city halls.

At 3209 feet, Scafell Pike is the highest mountain in England. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scafell_Pike
